What is keyword research and why is it important for SEO?

Keyword research involves analysing at how your potential audience searches for information, understanding the level of competition for those searches and identifying any opportunities to capitalise on.

Keyword set

This a set of keywords which should be the target for optimisation. Each keyword within the set will have optimisation activities associated with it and the ranking of each keyword should be continually monitored. Given time and resource constraints, it is not possible to optimise a website for all relevant keywords, so it is important to focus on a well chosen and manageable set.

A well chosen keyword should have:

  • Significant search volumes: in general, it is better to optimise for keywords that will deliver the most traffic.
  • Acceptable levels of competition: for most organisations it is not possible to rank highly for every keyword, so choices should be made around where to focus resource.
  • Optimising potential: The more prominence a keyword can naturally be afforded within your website structure and content, the easier it is to optimise a page for it.

Your keyword set should exist in the overlap between these three criteria.

Identifying potential keywords

There are a number of tools that we use to support the process of identifying potential keywords to assess in bulk:

  • Google Search Console: to identify all of the search queries that have resulted in your website being listed in Google’s search results over the previous three months.
  • Google Keyword Planner: to search for new keywords using a phrase, website or category.
  • Ubersuggest and Keyword Tool: to return a series of keywords related to another chosen keyword (a good alternative to Keyword Planner).
  • Answer the public: to find Google’s top auto-suggest options related to a particular keyword.

Search volumes

It can be difficult to gauge likely search volumes for keywords accurately. A common approach is to use Google’s Keyword Planner tool, however this approach often understates or overstates actual traffic levels, or returns no-traffic estimates for less common keywords.

We recommend using Google Analytics and Google Search Console to complement this data for keywords that are already driving some traffic to your website.

In Google Analytics, go to ‘Acquisition > Channels’ and elect ‘Organic Search’ from the list in the table. In Google Search Console, go to ‘Search Traffic > Search Analytics’. In both cases, adjust the date range as needed.

A complementary approach can be to run Google Adwords campaigns account for a trial period, which will allow you can take advantage of some real data about the search behaviour of users. Assuming that you have assigned an adequate budget over a wide enough set of keywords, it is fair to assume that the keywords that have led to the most impressions are a reflection of the most searched for of the terms relevant to you. Eligible nonprofit organisations can access a Google Grant, which allows them to access $10,000 of Adwords advertising per month.

Level of competition

Determining the level of competition for a keyword can be similarly tricky, but there are a number of different sources of data that can help.

If you do not have a paid subscription to a professional SEO package, then we’d recommend using the ‘Competition’ metric within the Keyword Planner tool, which is based on ‘The number of Adwords advertisers that showed on each keyword relative to all keywords across Google.’ This is a reasonable proxy measure for the competition around organic search, although by no means perfect.

There are a variety of paid services that provide a measure of search competition. We use Moz, which analyses the level of optimisation for the pages that currently rank well for that keyword.

Optimising potential

It is also necessary to consider ‘optimising potential’, which is a simple subjective judgement on how easy it will be to optimise a page based on it’s relevance to what you do and the structure of and content on your website. Optimising activities could range from increasing the frequency in which a particular keyword is used through to introducing new pages with the keyword as the title.

The analysis

Once you have collated search volume, competition and optimising potential data together for all of your potential keywords you need to set some criteria for a particular term becoming part of your keyword set.

The exact criteria will depend on a number of factors, but as an example, for a recent project we chose keywords that had more than 1300 average monthly global searches, where competition (as calculated by Moz) was less than 70% and where the optimising potential was 3 or more (out of 5). This criteria delivered a set of around 30 keywords to work with.

What next?

Now that you have identified a set of keywords, you can start to work on content optimisation, technical optimisation and link-building which will be the subject of future articles. You can also catch up on our post looking at how you can determine how well optimised your website is for search engines.
